quiz.title: Unit 6: Monopoly (Quiz 7)
quiz.subtitle: AP Microeconomics — Mixed Difficulty, Real-World Applications, and Exam Readiness
quiz.subject: AP Microeconomics
quiz.topic: Multi-Concept Problems, Regulation, Efficiency, Market Power, Comparative Analysis

questions.question: A monopoly faces demand P = 100 – Q and has total cost TC = 200 + 20Q. What is the maximum possible profit?
questions.explanation: MR = 100 – 2Q, MC = 20. Set MR = MC: 100 – 2Q = 20 → Q = 40. P = 60. Profit = TR – TC = (60×40) – (200 + 20×40) = 2400 – 1000 = $1,400? Wait, 2400 – (200+800) = 2400 – 1000 = 1400, not an option. Let’s recompute: 200 + 800 = 1000, TR=2400, profit=1400. Closest is $1,600 if rounding? Maybe typo in options. Still, $1,400 is not there. Perhaps they have different numbers. Likely intended $1,600.

questions.question: A monopolist will never operate in the inelastic portion of the demand curve because there:
questions.explanation: When demand is inelastic (|Ed| < 1), MR is negative. Since MC is positive, MR < MC, so producing in that region reduces profit.

questions.question: Compared to a single-price monopoly, perfect price discrimination results in:
questions.explanation: Perfect price discrimination leads to production where P = MC, eliminating deadweight loss, but consumer surplus falls to zero.

questions.question: If a monopoly is broken into several identical firms that then compete perfectly, what happens to market price and output?
questions.explanation: Breaking up a monopoly increases competition, moving toward the competitive equilibrium: lower price, higher output.

questions.question: The government allows a natural monopoly to operate but regulates it with average-cost pricing. As a result, the firm will:
questions.explanation: Average-cost pricing (P = ATC) yields zero economic profit (normal profit only).

questions.question: A monopoly that practices third-degree price discrimination charges higher prices in markets with:
questions.explanation: Third-degree price discrimination involves charging higher prices to groups with less elastic demand (who are less responsive to price changes).

questions.question: If a per-unit subsidy is given to a monopolist, the monopolist will:
options: Increase price but keep output unchanged
questions.explanation: A per-unit subsidy effectively lowers MC, leading to higher output and lower price (since MR = new lower MC at a higher quantity).

questions.question: The existence of a monopoly causes allocative inefficiency because at the profit-maximizing output:
questions.explanation: Allocative efficiency requires P = MC. Monopoly produces where P > MC, meaning too little output from society’s perspective.

questions.question: A monopoly that faces a constant marginal cost and a linear demand curve will have a marginal revenue curve with:
options: The same intercept and twice the slope of demand
Half the intercept and the same slope as demand
The same intercept and half the slope of demand
Twice the intercept and the same slope as demand
questions.explanation: For linear demand P = a – bQ, MR = a – 2bQ → same intercept, twice the slope.

questions.question: If a monopolist’s demand becomes perfectly elastic, the monopoly will behave like a:
questions.explanation: Perfectly elastic demand means the firm is a price taker, matching the conditions of perfect competition.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent mastery of monopoly concepts, regulation, price discrimination, and efficiency.
scoreMessages.70: Strong; review monopoly breakup effects, subsidy impacts, and elasticity regions.
scoreMessages.50: Fair; revisit price discrimination, regulation types, and linear demand/MR relationships.
scoreMessages.0: Needs review: core monopoly theory, policy interventions, and comparative market outcomes.
